case_name: Pratap Singh and Bachan Singh v. Gurbaksh Singh

facts.text: Gurbaksh Singh was a Forester in the Punjab Forest Department.

anchor.surface_text: Gurbaksh Singh respondent in the two appeals, was a Forester in the Punjab Forest Department. Pratap Singh, appellant in Criminal Appeal number 128 of 1959, was, at the relevant time, Chief Conservator of Forests, Punjab.

facts.text: Pratap Singh was Chief Conservator of Forests, Punjab at the relevant time.

anchor.surface_text: Pratap Singh, appellant in Criminal Appeal number 128 of 1959, was, at the relevant time, Chief Conservator of Forests, Punjab. Bachan Singh, appellant in the other appeal, was Divisional Forest Officer, Amritsar.

facts.text: Bachan Singh was Divisional Forest Officer, Amritsar.

anchor.surface_text: Bachan Singh, appellant in the other appeal, was Divisional Forest Officer, Amritsar. It appears that in the year 1950 the respondent supplied three lacs cubic feet of timber to the various ordnance Depots under orders of the then Chief Conservator of Forests.

facts.text: In the year 1950 the respondent supplied three lacs cubic feet of timber to the various ordnance Depots under orders of the then Chief Conservator of Forests.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in the year 1950 the respondent supplied three lacs cubic feet of timber to the various ordnance Depots under orders of the then Chief Conservator of Forests. In 1954, the then Chief Conservator of Forests sent a letter to the respondent alleging that there had been a short supply in the timber which was sent to the Ordnance Depot at Chhoke and that there had been a loss of Rs. 11,366 to the Government.

facts.text: In 1954, the then Chief Conservator of Forests sent a letter to the respondent alleging short supply to Ordnance Depot at Chhoke and loss of Rs. 11,366 to the Government.

anchor.surface_text: In 1954, the then Chief Conservator of Forests sent a letter to the respondent alleging that there had been a short supply in the timber which was sent to the Ordnance Depot at Chhoke and that there had been a loss of Rs. 11,366 to the Government.

facts.text: By order conveyed in letter dated July 16, 1956, State Government directed Chief Conservator to recover Rs. 1,136 from respondent Gurbaksh Singh.

anchor.surface_text: By an order companyveyed in a letter dated July 16, 1956, the State Government directed the Chief Conservator of Forests to recover ten per cent. of the loss i.e. Rs. 1,136 and odd annas from the respondent Gurbaksh Singh.

facts.text: Gurbaksh Singh instituted a suit in the Court of the Senior Subordinate Judge, Amritsar for declaration that the order of recovery was void.

anchor.surface_text: Gurbaksh Singh then instituted a suit in the Court of the Senior Subordinate Judge, Amritsar for a declaration that the order of recovery made against him was void and without effect.

facts.text: Petition under Art. 226 dismissed by Punjab High Court on May 20,1957.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was followed by a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution which was, however, dismissed by the Punjab High Court on May 20,1957.

facts.text: Circular letter dated January 25, 1953 issued by Chief Secretary to Punjab Government instructing government servants to exhaust departmental remedies before court.

anchor.surface_text: the attention of the latter was drawn to a circular letter issued by the Chief Secretary on January 25, 1953. The letter has been quoted in extenso in the judgment of the High Court and was in these terms I am directed to say that the question of Government servants having recourse to Courts of law in matters arising out of their employment or companyditions of service has been engaging the attention of Government for some time past and it is companysidered necessary to lay down that in the matter of grievances arising out of a Government servants employment or companyditions of service the proper companyrse is to seek redress from the appropriate departmental and Governmental authorities.

facts.text: Under Secretary sent memorandum to Chief Conservator Pratap Singh drawing attention to circular and asking action against respondent.

anchor.surface_text: When the summons in the suit instituted in the Court of the Senior Subordinate Judge, Amritsar, was served on the State Government, the Under Secretary to the said Government in the Forest and Animal Husbandry Departments, sent a memorandum to the Chief Conservator of Forests in which the attention of the latter was drawn to a circular letter issued by the Chief Secretary on January 25, 1953.

facts.text: Pratap Singh sent copy of memorandum to Conservator of Forests, South Circle, directing proceedings against respondent per circular.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of this memorandum, the appellant Pratap Singh sent a companyy thereof to the Conservator of Forests, South Circle, and directed that the respondent should be proceeded with in accordance with the instructions aforesaid and a companyy of the proceedings recorded and orders passed in the case should be forwarded to him.

facts.text: Conservator of Forests, South Circle passed office order appointing Bachan Singh to hold enquiry against respondent.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of the said orders, the Conservator of Forests, South Circle, passed an office order appointing Bachan Singh, appellant in Criminal Appeal No. 129 of 1959, to hold an enquiry against the respondent for having companytravened the instructions companytained in the circular letter quoted above.

facts.text: Bachan Singh drew up charge-sheet against respondent on or about August 30, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Bachan Singh then drew up a charge-sheet against the respondent and asked him to submit an explanation in writing within 15 days. In the charge-sheet it was stated that the respondent had gone to a companyrt of law before exhausting all his departmental remedies and this was companytrary to official propriety and subversive of good discipline. The charge-sheet appears to have been drawn up on or about August 30, 1957.

facts.text: On September 14,1957, respondent made application to High Court alleging appellants committed contempt.

anchor.surface_text: Then, on September 14,1957, the respondent made an application to the High Court to the effect that the two appellants had companymitted companytempt of companyrt punishable under s. 3 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1952.

facts.text: Punjab High Court judgment and order dated November 5, 1958 in Cr. Nos. 20 and 27 of 1957 found appellants guilty under s.3 Contempt of Courts Act 1952, directed abandon departmental proceedings, warned against complying with circular.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated November 5, 1958, of the Punjab High Court in Cr. Nos. 20 and 27 of 1957. ... by which it found the two appellants guilty of an offence punishable under s. 3 of the Contempt of the Courts Act, 1952  XXXII of 1952  and directed them, by way of punishment, to abandon the departmental proceedings which had been taken against the respondent Gurbaksh Singh ... and warned them against companyplying with the said instructions.

facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 128 and 129 of 1959 from Punjab High Court on certificate under Art. 134(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeals Nos. 128 and 129 of 1959. Appeals from the judgment and order dated November 5, 1958, of the Punjab High Court in Cr. Nos. 20 and 27 of 1957.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeals heard together, judgment January 29, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. January 29. The Judgment of Das and Subba Rao JJ, was delivered by Das, J. Dayal, J. delivered a separate Judgment.

facts.text: High Court issued notice to appellants and after hearing found them guilty but lenient due to complying with government instructions.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court issued numberice to the appellants and after hearing the parties came to the companyclusion that though the appellants were clearly guilty of an offence punishable under s. 3 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1952, they were merely endeavouring to companyply with the instructions of the Government, the legality or propriety of which they had numberreason to doubt.

facts.text: Respondent filed two petitions on September 14, 1957 giving rise to Cr. Nos. 20 and 27 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the respondent filed two petitions on September 14, 1957, in the Punjab High Court which gave rise to two cases number. 20 and 27 of 1957.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeals, found appellants guilty of contempt.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, companye to the companyclusion that the appellants were guilty of companytempt of the Court of the Senior Subordinate Judge, Amritsar and in awarding the sentence the High Court companyrectly took into companysideration the circumstance that the appellants were merely carrying out the instructions companytained in the circular letter. ... The appeals are accordingly dismissed.

facts.text: Dayal J dissented, held no contempt.

anchor.surface_text: RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J,-I have held the advantage of perusing the judgment of my learned brother, S. Das, J., but regret my inability to agree that the appellants are guilty of companytempt of Court.

facts.text: Circular contained executive instructions, not rule of service.

anchor.surface_text: committed contempt of court punishable under s. 3 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1952.

What, after all, is contempt of court? To speak generally, contempt of court may be said to be constituted by any conduct that tends to bring the authority and administration of the law into disrespect or disregard, or to interfere with or prejudice parties litigant or their witnesses during the litigation.

concepts.interpretation: Court adopts Oswald's definition focusing on interference with or prejudice to parties during litigation.

issues.text: the question before us is not so much the validity of the circular letter in the abstract, but the propriety of the action taken against the respondent on the basis of the circular letter at a time when his suit was awaiting decision in the court of the Senior Subordinate Judge at Amritsar

anchor.surface_text: It should perhaps be made clear at the very outset that the question before us is not so much the validity of the circular letter in the abstract, but the propriety of the action taken against the respondent on the basis of the circular letter at a time when his suit was awaiting decision in the court of the Senior Subordinate Judge at Amritsar.

issues.text: whether the petition dated September 14, 1957 by which the respondent prayed for action against the appellants for contempt of court stated that the contempt was in respect of the High Court in which a writ petition under Art. 226 had been filed but the High Court held the appellants guilty of interference with the suit pending in the subordinate court

anchor.surface_text: Firstly, it has been argued that the petition dated September 14, 1957, by which the respondent prayed for action against the appellants for contempt of court, stated that the contempt was in respect of the High Court in which a writ petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution had been filed.

issues.text: on a fair construction of the terms of the circular letter ... it should be held that it did not constitute an interference with the course of justice, inasmuch as it did not impose any absolute ban on a Government servant to have recourse to a court of law ... but merely imposed an obligation ... to exhaust his departmental remedies before taking recourse to a court of law

anchor.surface_text: The second point which has been taken on behalf of the appellants is that on a fair construction of the terms of the circular letter on which the two appellants took action against the respondent, it should be held that it did not constitute an interference with the course of justice, inasmuch as it did not impose any absolute ban on a Government servant to have recourse to a court of law for the redress of his grievances arising out of his employment or conditions of his service, but merely imposed an obligation on a Government servant to exhaust his departmental remedies before taking recourse to a court of law.

holdings.text: The first point urged on behalf of the appellants must be overruled.

anchor.surface_text: In view of these allegations in the second petition filed on September 14, 1957, the first point urged on behalf of the appellants must be overruled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Two petitions filed on same day; second explicitly alleged interference with subordinate court suit, not just writ petition.

holdings.text: The appellants were guilty of contempt of the Court of the Senior Subordinate Judge, Amritsar.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, come to the conclusion that the appellants were guilty of contempt of the Court of the Senior Subordinate Judge, Amritsar and in awarding the sentence the High Court correctly took into consideration the circumstance that the appellants were merely carrying out the instructions contained in the circular letter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Departmental proceedings during pending suit had tendency to pressure withdrawal, interfering with course of justice per Oswald definition and tendency test.

holdings.text: On a fair construction of the terms of the circular letter... it did constitute an interference with the course of justice.

anchor.surface_text: The second point which has been taken on behalf of the appellants is that on a fair construction of the terms of the circular letter on which the two appellants took action against the respondent, it should be held that it did not constitute an interference with the course of justice,...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even if no absolute ban, timing of disciplinary action during litigation creates tendency to coerce litigant, constituting contempt.

holdings.text: Appellant Pratap Singh... was guilty of contempt of court.

anchor.surface_text: As to the third point that appellant Pratap Singh took no action beyond endorsing the memorandum of the Under Secretary, we have already dealt with it and pointed out that he not merely endorsed the memorandum of the Under Secretary but directed the Conservator of Forests, South Circle, to institute a proceeding against the respondent...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pratap Singh directed subordinate to proceed against respondent per circular, not mere endorsement.

holdings.text: The question is not whether the action in fact interfered, but whether it had a tendency to interfere with the due course of justice.

anchor.surface_text: The question is not whether the action in fact interfered, but whether it had a tendency to interfere with the due course of justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied tendency test to facts; proceedings tend to coerce withdrawal.

holdings.text: In awarding the sentence the High Court correctly took into consideration the circumstance that the appellants were merely carrying out the instructions contained in the circular letter. Though that circumstance does not afford a defence to the charge, it is undoubtedly a consideration relevant to the sentence.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, come to the conclusion that the appellants were guilty of contempt of the Court of the Senior Subordinate Judge, Amritsar and in awarding the sentence the High Court correctly took into consideration the circumstance that the appellants were merely carrying out the instructions contained in the circular letter. Though that circumstance does not afford a defence to the charge, it is undoubtedly a consideration relevant to the sentence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Compliance with executive instructions mitigates punishment but does not excuse contempt.

holdings.text: There are no grounds for interference with the judgment and order of the High Court dated November 5, 1958. The appeals are accordingly dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: This disposes of all the points urged on behalf of the appellants. In our opinion, there are no grounds for interference with the judgment and order of the High Court dated November 5, 1958. The appeals are accordingly dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All arguments rejected; High Court order upheld.

holdings.text: We... proceeded... on the footing that the circular letter contained executive instructions only and did not embody a rule governing the conditions of service... we are expressing no opinion on those other considerations.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Advocates for the parties were, however, agreed that no rule laying down the conditions of service of Government servants serving in the department to which the respondent belonged imposed an obligation similar to that imposed by the circular letter. We have, therefore, proceeded in this case on the footing that the circular letter contained executive instructions only and did not embody a rule governing the conditions of service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parties agreed; court assumes for decision but expressly no opinion if it were a service rule.

holdings.text: The appellants were not guilty of contempt of Court.

anchor.surface_text: RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J,-I have held the advantage of perusing the judgment of my learned brother, S. Das, J., but regret my inability to agree that the appellants are guilty of contempt of Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dissenting opinion: departmental action for indiscipline not contempt; distinguishes precedents.
